raw_comment:
What do you notice? 
-The applicants with parents on the wealthier end of the spectrum who are not legacies are less likely to get accepted then poorer non-legacy applicants. 
-People with rich, alumni parents are the most likely to be accepted into the university. 
-Where the rich alumni admissions spike, the rich non-alumni applicant admissions drop. 

What do you wonder? 
-Why are these students applying? What is their reasoning behind their applications? 

What’s the relation? 
Both of my parents are alumnis at Michigan State University. It thus follows that I’ve grown up going to campus- I love it up there, however that doesn’t mean that I want to go there. However, a lot of people want (or expect) me to go there because of my parents. I wonder then, what the pressure on the legacies is. Perhaps the Ivy Leagues favor legacies. But, could it also be that a lot of the legacies applying there apply because they are legacies? 

Title: 
A Legacy of Parental Pressure
ace_sentences: Some applicants are non-legacy applicants.
Some applicants are legacy applicants.
Some applicants have wealthy parents.
Some applicants have poor parents.
Some applicants have alumni parents.
Some applicants have non-alumni parents.
Non-legacy applicants with wealthy parents are less likely to be accepted than non-legacy applicants with poor parents.
Applicants with wealthy alumni parents are most likely to be accepted into the university.
In some cases, the admissions rate of wealthy alumni applicants increases.
Where the admissions rate of wealthy alumni applicants increases, the admissions rate of wealthy non-alumni applicants decreases.
I wonder why these students apply to the university.
I wonder what reasoning these students have for their applications.
My mother is an alumna of Michigan State University.
My father is an alumnus of Michigan State University.
I grew up going to the campus of Michigan State University.
I love the campus of Michigan State University.
I do not necessarily want to go to Michigan State University.
Some people want me to go to Michigan State University because of my parents.
Some people expect me to go to Michigan State University because of my parents.
I wonder what pressure legacy applicants have.
Perhaps Ivy League universities favor legacy applicants.
I wonder whether many legacy applicants apply because they are legacy applicants.
The title is "A Legacy of Parental Pressure".
